article_title: Cine: Spanish Influences on Early Cinema in the Philippines
text:
Published 2003 in Manila / Author: Nick Deocampo / Publisher: National Commission for Culture and the Arts

Cine is the first book in Nick Deocampo’s proposed multivolume history of cinema in the Philippines. In his introduction, “The Forgotten History of a Popular Culture,” Deocampo provides the framework, assumptions, and methodology of his historiography. He characterizes early cinema in the Philippines as being formed in the crucible of colonialism, between Hispanismo and Anglo-Sajonismo. As such, early cinema could not be called “Filipino” but had to undergo the processes of indigenization and nationalization.

Chapter 1, “Cinema and Language,” focuses on how the Spanish language served as a homogenizing force in the formation of film culture in the Philippines. It points to how Filipinos adapted Spanish-derived terms and concepts pertaining to cinema, as well as how early films produced and exhibited in the Philippines employed Spanish intertitles and dubbing.

Chapter 2, “Cinema and Revolution,” provides a chronology of events from the heralding of cinema’s arrival in the Philippines in 1896, to its arrival in 1897, and the subsequent production of films from 1898 onward. It expounds on the theme of the Philippine revolution against Spain and the United States and its implications—on the one hand, for the representation of Filipinos in Spanish and American films and, on the other, for the development of cinema in the Philippines during this period.

Chapter 3, “Cinema and Culture,” details the complex relationship between theater and cinema in the cultural life of fin de siècle Filipinos. It demonstrates the cultural dominance of theater, as well as the affinity between cinema and theater even early on.

Chapter 4, “Cinema Comes into Its Own,” gives an account of how cinema eventually overtook theater as a dominant popular form. It gives a picture of cosmopolitan Manila that preferred European films over American “junk” films.

Chapter 5, “Spanish Influences on Tagalog Cinema,” moves beyond the period of early cinema and allows for a wider view of Philippine film history, over which Hispanismo remains apparent in language, material culture, aesthetics, viewership, and ideology. Finally, Deocampo outlines the challenges posed against Hispanismo in Philippine film in the form of American influences and the anti-hegemonic aspirations of an emergent national cinema.   Written by Patrick Campos

Published 2008 in Manila / Author: Nicanor G. Tiongson / Publisher: University of Santo Tomas Publishing House

The Cinema of Manuel Conde is the first book-length biography of a Filipino film artist, chronicled in the context of Philippine film history. As such, it illuminates the sociohistorical milieu of Manuel Conde, at the same time that it offers a critical appraisal of the artist’s oeuvre. It features hundreds of rare photographs, publicity posters, production stills, periodical clippings, souvenirs and family keepsakes, handwritten pages of shooting scripts, and costume design sketches by Conde’s longtime collaborator and friend, National Artist Carlos “Botong” Francisco. The book, as such, visually encapsulates the Golden Age of Philippine Cinema, which Conde helped shape. A complete and annotated filmography is also provided.

Tiongson periodizes the life of Conde from his humble beginnings to his entry into the movies (1915-45), from the establishment of his MC Pictures to his excursions to Hollywood and the European film festival circuit (1945-52), from his commercial successes as studio director of genre films (1953-58) to the creation of his sociopolitical films (1959-63), and from his extra-filmic endeavors to his gradual retirement from filmmaking (1964-85).

The book details many of Conde’s achievements. Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1941, was the first film to be based on a metrical romance and the first “color” movie in the country. Prinsipe Paris (Prince Paris), 1949, was the first to use real blades in swordplay. Genghis Khan, 1950, was the first Filipino film to compete internationally and to have garnered worldwide acclaim.

In the concluding chapter, Tiongson evaluates the contributions of Conde to the formation of Filipino national cinema. He particularly praises Conde’s cinema for its “transmission and revitalization of Philippine folk literature,” “revaluation of customs and traditions,” “examination of Philippine issues,” “innovation on the genres,” and “for opening Filipino cinema to the world” (184-202 passim). These contributions, according to Tiongson, combine world-class Filipino film artistry, a regard for both the local bakya (lowbrow) mass audiences and the intelligentsia, and sensitivity toward the sociopolitical issues of the times.  Written by Patrick Campos

Published 1977, Manila / Editor: Monina A. Mercado / Publisher: A. R. Mercado Management Inc

The first golden age of Philippine cinema, which began shortly after World War II and hastened into decline by the 1960s, was the heyday of the studio system. And one of the key figures of this period was Narcisa Buencamino de Leon or Doña Sisang, who co-founded LVN Pictures in 1938. Along with Sampaguita Pictures and Premiere Productions, LVN was part of the “Big Three” that collectively churned out around 65 percent of Filipino movies produced from 1946 to 1960.

In just over two decades, Doña Sisang produced more than 350 movies and transformed LVN Pictures from a joint venture among family friends into one of the country’s preeminent studios. Her story is told in this book, which does triple duty as a definitive biography, a critical examination of de Leon’s legacy, and a brief history of a specific period in the local movie industry.

The book features anecdote-filled essays penned by seasoned journalists, such as Paulyn P. Sicam, Lorna K. Tirol, and Nestor U. Torre as well as contributors Manuel G. Chaves and Babsy Paredes. Mercado’s “Sine: A Brief History” and “A Mosaic of Memories” are the first and last chapters, opening and closing the book by putting into context the forces that allowed for the existence of LVN and the industry’s “Grand Old Lady.” Torre’s “Doña Sisang: Her Times, Her Studio” is an in-depth look into how de Leon built and ruled her own studio, which gave rise to some of Philippine cinema’s most enduring leading ladies and men. Chaves’s “LVN: Still in the Movies” is a rich portfolio of annotated production stills from LVN’s film vault, giving readers a glimpse of movies and stars from a bygone era, made all the more rare and precious because of the country’s lack of a film archive. Sicam and Paredes’s “The Directors’ Director” dissects de Leon’s complex and sometimes contentious relationships with LVN’s stable of directors. And finally, Tirol’s “The Starmaker,” “The Musicmaker,” and “The Movie Stars’ Matriarch” bring to light de Leon’s different roles in LVN, as seen through the prism of memories from her collaborators, discoveries, and friends.

What emerges is a portrait of de Leon as a shrewd entrepreneur, a canny impresario, a steely matriarch, and a confident stylemaker, perennially clad in her customary outfit of baro’t saya and corcho (slippers). She was a power player in a baro’t saya outfit whose unabashed nationalism, irrepressible commercialism, and escapist bent shaped a signature look and sound for LVN’s movies, even though they were made by different directors.

The “LVN style” had de Leon’s fingerprints all over it. No detail was too trivial or complex for her handle, as she “read scripts, decided on projects, supervised casting, designed costumes, viewed rushes, all down the line,” explains Torre. Her decided partiality for romance—the rural kind as well as the traditional awit and korido (metrical romances)—accounts for the attention she lavished on LVN’s productions of Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1941, Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura), 1949, and Prinsipe Teñoso (Prince Teñoso), 1954. That these stories were focused on noble and chaste love was no accident. De Leon had a strong religious streak, and her devotion to Catholicism was apparent in her demand that LVN movies carry moral lessons and feature no sex, just love scenes that were limited to a wholesome kiss on the cheek.

Her penny-pinching nature made her reluctant to spend on marketing and public relations, so she paired up LVN’s male and female stars and created “love teams” instead. “Magpa-chismis kayo” (make other people gossip about you), she would tell them, and then allowed the rumor mill to do all the publicity work for her. It was a clever solution, though it did inadvertently contribute to the emergence and continued existence of the love team as an institutionalized fame-generating tactic in Philippine showbiz—a dubious legacy, if there ever was one.

“Kung ano ang kikita” (whatever makes money) neatly sums up how de Leon chose what films to make. As such, LVN was best known for crowd-pleasing swordplay costume movies and comedies. But thanks to the persistence of Manuel, the de Leon matriarch’s son, LVN was also the same studio that produced director Lamberto Avellana’s Anak Dalita (The Ruins), 1956, a film that could only be deemed a blockbuster if the moviegoing public could not get enough of desolate, realistic dramas about how Filipinos rebuilt their life after World War II amid rubble-strewn poverty and loss-ridden misery. Anak Dalita won a host of awards, including Best Film, at the 1956 Asia-Pacific Film Festival, but that didn’t lead to a sudden surge in LVN movies imbued with socially conscious themes or gritty realism. No surprise there. In the chapter “The Director’s Director,” Sicam and Paredes interview Avellana, who recalls that Doña Sisang asked him, “Bakit mo ipapakita sa tao na mahirap sila?” (Why show people that they are poor?).

Tirol starts “The Movie Stars’ Matriarch” with a revelation about legendary actress Rosa Rosal. A serious thespian who frequently did daring or kontrabida (antagonist) roles in LVN pictures (she was also in Anak Dalita), Rosal had no qualms about wearing bathing suits or kissing her co-stars. But she did name two of her fears in life: God and Doña Sisang.

That remark was telling, but it was not about de Leon’s tyrannical ways. Instead, like this book, it was a tribute to her shrewd acumen, a sign of enduring respect for a pioneering woman whose drive and ambition helped give birth to the first Pax Filipiniana in Philippine cinema.  Written by Eileen Ang

article_title: Dream Factories of a Former Colony: American Fantasies, Philippine Cinema
text:
Published 2010 in Minneapolis / Author: Jose B. Capino / Publisher: University of Minnesota Press

Capino’s main presupposition is that Philippine cinema, since its independence from the United Statesin 1946, has continued to exhibit “transcultural imaginings defined by an American presence.” He argues that plots, figures, and settings in Filipino films betray American “daydreams” that accompany the complex and concurrent processes of decolonization and globalization.

Divided into three sections—“Visions of Empire,” “Transnational Imaginings,” and “Global Ambitions”—the book offers close readings of films in the light of their sociohistorical contexts, in order to flesh out “the constellations of American fantasies” that define Philippine cinema. Chapter 1, “Terror Is a Man: Exploiting the Horrors of Empire,” focuses on the Blood Island B-movie series directed by Eddie Romero and Gerardo de Leon for the American market and how these obliquely “dispatched images of US-instigated violence in the Third World to a nation often forgetful of its imperial doings.”

Chapter 2, “My Brother Is Not a Pig: American Benevolence and Philippine Sovereignty,” reads how three films of decolonization—namely, Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo (Once a Moth), 1976; PX, 1984; and Sa Kuko ng Agila (In the Claws of an Eagle), 1989—“enjoin a contemplation of the biopolitics of US military presence in the former colony” and critique “America’s infidelity to its own ideals.”

Chapter 3, “(Not) Searching for My Father: GI Babies and Postcolonial Futures,” teases out the Filipinos’ ambivalent feelings toward nation and empire through the social realist, at the same time parabolic and allegorical, films about Amerasians in the Philippines seeking to reunite with their white fathers who abandoned them. The chapter zeroes in on Hellow, Soldier, 1975, Olongapo… The Great American Dream, 1987, and Batang PX (Phil-American Boy), 1997.

The second section of the book locates Filipinos in the United States. Chapter 4, “The Migrant Woman’s Tale: On Loving and Leaving Nations,” dwells on the films ’Merika (America), 1984, and Sana Maulit Muli (Second Chances), 1995, about women who migrate to the United States but are enticed, for one reason or another, to return home. Both films, according to Capino, challenge the myth of American dream and the patriarchal limitations of Filipino nationalism.

Chapter 5, “Filipino American Dreams: The Cultural Politics of Diaspora Films,” analyzes films made by Filipino Americans—namely, The Debut, 2000, The Flip Side, 2001, and Cavite , 2005. Capino here demonstrates how second-generation Filipino Americans struggle to retrieve usable ethnic identities in the face of the American dream that has ruined the older generation of diasporic Filipinos.

The last section critiques what may be considered examples of Philippine cinema’s “global fantasy” films, produced with the borrowed force of US-influenced global culture. The gay movies Macho Dancer, 1988, Sibak (Midnight Dancers), 1994, and Burlesk King (King of Stripteasers), 1999, “aimed at First World audiences,” are the focus of chapter 6, “Naked Brown Brothers: Exhibitionism and Festival Cinema,” which distinguishes between the films’ exoticization of Filipinos and their political agenda.

Chapter 7, “Philippine Cinema’s Fatal Attractions: Appropriating Hollywood,” evaluates the way Kasalanan Bang Sambahin Ka? (Is It a Sin to Worship You?), 1990, and Loretta, 1994, appropriate and restage popular American spectacles, through which Filipino actors and spectators imagine themselves as participating in globalization and global culture. The book closes with the short “coda,” “A Tale of Two Brothers,” in which the film Dubai, 2005, gives Capino the occasion to suggest that, after six decades of independence, “some colonial phantoms have already been banished from the [Philippine] map.”  Written by Patrick Campos

article_title: Film: American Influences on Philippine Cinema
text:
Published 2011 in Mandaluyong City / Author: Nick Deocampo / Publisher: Anvil Publishing Inc

Film is the second in Nick Deocampo’s multivolume history of cinema in the Philippines. In the introduction, “Colonial Beginnings of Native Cinema,” Deocampo discusses the confluence of Hispanismo, Anglo-Sajonismo, and Filipinismo, which constitute early cinema in the Philippines. Chapter 1, “Cinema and Colonization,” focuses on the concurrent births of cinema and nation, in the midst of the transition from Spanish to American colonization, between 1899 and 1902. It traces the beginnings of filmic representations of the Philippines in newsreels, reenactments, and actual on-location footage produced by Americans to depict the Spanish-American War in the Pacific.

Chapter 2, “Pioneer American Filmmakers,” looks into the works of three Americans—James Henry White, Elias Burton Holmes, and C. Fred Ackerman—who were motivated by the ongoing war to produce films about the Philippines. Deocampo evaluates the “imperialist gaze” that influenced the production of these representations and their use of cinematic screen space.

Chapter 3, “Films about the Colony,” critiques American actualities, fiction films, educational films, documentaries, lecture films, and film catalogues that provided the bases for the imperialist project of the United States into the 20th century.

Chapter 4, “Pre-Hollywood Manila,” shifts the focus of the chronicle to “Eurocentric Manila,” which, at this time, was dominated by French, rather than American, films. Deocampo argues that this historical juncture of cinema in the Philippines exemplifies the complex beginnings of “native” cinema, which resulted in its being “hybrid.”

Chapter 5, “A Nascent Film Industry,” plots the growth of film business in the Philippines from 1899 to the 1920s. It also traces the Americanization of local film culture and the spread of cinema in the Visayas, specifically in Iloilo and Cebu.

Chapter 6, “Early American Film Productions,” analyzes the careers of Americans who accelerated film activity in the Philippines by producing feature-length, narrative, and spectacular films prior to World War II, such as the two biopics of Jose Rizal in 1912 and Zamboanga in 1937. It chronicles the rise of the “native” film industry in the same period.

Chapter 7, “Roots of Hollywood Dominance,” traces the rise of Hollywood as a “global” and dominant cinema in the Philippines from World War I onward. Deocampo asserts that Hispanismo still posed a challenge to Hollywood in the country, but he also outlines the industrial and cultural tactics of American cinema that were eventually imitated by the Philippine film industry.

Chapter 8, “Hollywood’s Rupture and Return,” assesses the implications of the Japanese occupation for Hollywood’s presence in the Philippines. While World War II suddenly halted the influx of Hollywood in the Philippines, Deocampo demonstrates not only how Hollywood was able to “return with a vengeance” but also how the heroic image of Americans was further reinvigorated after the war.

Chapter 9, “Destination: Hollywood,” pictures Hollywood as a “Mecca” for Filipino filmmakers who wished to either make it big in the United States or learn from American practices and transfer American technologies to the local industry.

In chapters 10-12, “Hollywood Influences on Technology and Economy,” “Hollywood Influences on Material Production and Aesthetics: Studio System, Film Genre, Star System,” and “Hollywood Influences on Language and Ideology,” Deocampo pulls away from early film history and broadly rereads Philippine film history “under the Hollywood spell.”  Written by Patrick Campos

Chapter 4, “Pre-Hollywood Manila,” shifts the focus of the chronicle to “Eurocentric Manila,” which, at this time, was dominated by French, rather than American, films. Deocampo argues that this historical juncture of cinema in the Philippines exemplifies the complex beginnings of “native” cinema, which resulted in its being “hybrid.”

Chapter 5, “A Nascent Film Industry,” plots the growth of film business in the Philippines from 1899 to the 1920s. It also traces the Americanization of local film culture and the spread of cinema in the Visayas, specifically in Iloilo and Cebu.

Chapter 6, “Early American Film Productions,” analyzes the careers of Americans who accelerated film activity in the Philippines by producing feature-length, narrative, and spectacular films prior to World War II, such as the two biopics of Jose Rizal in 1912 and Zamboanga in 1937. It chronicles the rise of the “native” film industry in the same period.

Chapter 7, “Roots of Hollywood Dominance,” traces the rise of Hollywood as a “global” and dominant cinema in the Philippines from World War I onward. Deocampo asserts that Hispanismo still posed a challenge to Hollywood in the country, but he also outlines the industrial and cultural tactics of American cinema that were eventually imitated by the Philippine film industry.

While World War II suddenly halted the influx of Hollywood in the Philippines, Deocampo demonstrates not only how Hollywood was able to “return with a vengeance” but also how the heroic image of Americans was further reinvigorated after the war.

Chapter 9, “Destination: Hollywood,” pictures Hollywood as a “Mecca” for Filipino filmmakers who wished to either make it big in the United States or learn from American practices and transfer American technologies to the local industry.

In chapters 10-12, “Hollywood Influences on Technology and Economy,” “Hollywood Influences on Material Production and Aesthetics: Studio System, Film Genre, Star System,” and “Hollywood Influences on Language and Ideology,” Deocampo pulls away from early film history and broadly rereads Philippine film history “under the Hollywood spell.”  Written by Patrick Campos

article_title: The Golden Years: Memorable Tagalog Movie Ads, 1946-1956, from the Collection of Danny Dolor
text:
Published 1994 in Manila / Authors: Ronald K. Constantino and Ricardo F. Lo / Publisher: Danny Dolor

This book features 362 ads of Tagalog movies shown from 1946 to 1956, selected from the extensive collection of Danny Dolor, a film aficionado and patron of Filipino art. Clearly, Dolor belongs to a small circle of movie fans who can personally afford to do something concrete and ultimately useful with his film collection.

A decade may seem too brief to merit a label as honorific as “Golden Age.” This period, however, is regarded as the heyday of the studio system. Prominent companies, such as Sampaguita Pictures, LVN, and Premiere, created and managed an impressive stable of stars, actors, directors, scriptwriters, and technical professionals who were bound by exclusive contracts. Eventually, each studio developed and banked on its own specialty genres. Similar to the “dream factory” of Hollywood, these studios churned out movies regularly, feeding a generation of Filipinos who flocked to the theaters to satisfy their hunger for films that reflected their own tastes and perspectives.

The Golden Years is an engaging experience for anyone with an inquisitive mind. Leafing through its 426 pages is like opening a treasure trove of pop trivia: character actor Berting Labra, known for his father-figure roles and stint as Fernando Poe Jr’s sidekick in bakbakan or action flicks, was once touted as “Wonder Boy.” Manuel Conde’s satiric Si Juan Tamad (Lazy Juan), 1947, was promoted as “A Laffterpiece,” playing on the Filipino penchant for sly puns and coining portmanteau words. Rogelio de la Rosa, the dapper leading man of Philippine movies, starred in Sword of the Avenger, 1948, with Hollywood starlet Sigrid Gurie.

The idea for this book may seem quaint, but it is helpful to remember that there are probably no existing copies of the movies that these ads promoted. In a country where the imperative for film preservation is carried out by an ardent few who have limited resources, these materials could very well be all that we have left of the past. As with all relics, they are remarkable in their own right. But they are also inadequate proofs of the existence of something that will never be again.  Written by Eileen Ang

article_title: Lino Brocka: The Artist and His Times
text:
Published 1993 in Manila / Editor: Mario A. Hernando / Publisher: Cultural Center of the Philippines

The book presents a compelling portrait of an acclaimed and controversial filmmaker whose brilliance was rudely extinguished by his abrupt passing. Divided into three main sections—“Articles,” “Reviews,” and “Interviews”—and supported by production stills, archival photographs, and other images, the book attempts to answer this question: who was Lino Brocka?

The responses, as provided by the selection of essays in this book, are resoundingly varied and reassuringly Brocka: entertainer, filmmaker, Filipino, global sensation, National Artist, agent provocateur.

The “Articles” section is composed of pieces from Mario Hernando (also the book’s editor), Jose “Butch” Dalisay Jr, Butch Francisco, Jo-Ann Maglipon, Agustin “Hammy” Sotto, Nestor U. Torre, and Johven Velasco, which explore Brocka’s creative and personal evolution, detailing his contributions to theater, television, and cinema as well as capturing his persona as an international artist and street parliamentarian.

The “Reviews” section features selected critiques of several Brocka films by preeminent Filipino scholars and critics, such as Hernando, Francisco, Grace Javier Alfonso, Pio de Castro III, Isagani R. Cruz, Nick Cruz, SJ, Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, Bienvenido Lumbera, Emmanuel Reyes, Alfredo Roces, Pablo Tariman, and Alfred Yuson. Critical essays from French film critics Charles Tesson and Alain Garasault are also included in the book. Taken together, these pieces are like artifacts from a time capsule, offering readers insights into how Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), 1975, Insiang, 1976, and Orapronobis (Fight for Us), 1989, among others, were received and regarded during Brocka’s prime.

The “Interviews” section, particularly those in the question-and-answer format, feature riveting exchanges between Brocka and Sotto, Justino Dormiendo, Fanny Garcia, and Ricardo Lo. Uttered so long ago, Brocka’s words still have the power to leap from the pages, collaring one’s attention with his unquenched passion for craft, country, life—not necessarily in that order.

Brocka, who died in a car accident in 1991, was a man whose contradictions “made him more human and complicated,” observes Hernando in the introduction. This view is reflected in the essays included in the book, which were mostly penned by scholars, experts, and creative professionals—people whose jobs require them to exercise a necessary detachment. Nevertheless, most of them were also Brocka’s friends, colleagues, and even occasional enemies. Yet despite their professional training, they were not immune to his magnetism or unmoved by his outrageousness.

This is not to say, however, that Lino Brocka: The Artist and His Times is a cloying tribute or a fawning exercise among colleagues, executed in print form. But it is certainly a labor of love, a mark of respect, and an act of remembrance for a fallen comrade who is sorely missed and needed. In death, Brocka’s reputation has acquired the patina of legend, turning his name into a shorthand for the gold standard in Filipino cinema. But many of Brocka’s works were rooted in specificity, serving as a fiery and bleak commentary on the social injustices and political oppression that blanketed a country that broke free from the shackles of a long, brutal dictatorship, only to find itself still lost despite reclaiming its democracy.

Given how globalization, digital technology, and independent distribution have changed the way we produce, watch, and market movies, does Brocka’s incendiary brand of cinema hold any allure to the current crop and succeeding generations of filmmakers? Yes, if this book is any measure. Because Brocka’s life itself is a timeless, exemplary model of how an artist can “fight the good fight”: by finding one’s distinctive vision and standing by it, despite the inevitable hits and misses that happen in the process.  Written by Eileen Ang

Published 1984 in Manila / Author: Isagani R. Cruz / With an Introduction by Bienvenido Lumbera / Publisher: National Book Store

Movie Times is an anthology of film articles, previously published in diverse newspapers and magazines. Illustrated and indexed, the book is divided into three parts: “Film in the Modern Filipino World,” “The Landscape of the Filipino Film,” and “A Gallery of Film Artists.” The second and third sections contain reviews arranged according to issues and filmmakers, respectively; the issues are komiks, first films, Filipinos as rebels, Filipinos abroad, “plagiarism, influence, and spoofs,” and mediocrity, while the film artists are directors Ishmael Bernal, Lino Brocka, Celso Ad. Castillo, Gerardo de Leon, Mike de Leon, Maryo J. delos Reyes, Marilou Diaz-Abaya, Laurice Guillen, Mario O’Hara, Fernando PoeJr, Eddie Romero, and scriptwriter Ricky Lee.

It is in the first section that the author’s critical essays are compiled: “Understanding Movies,” “Books on Films,” “Years in Review,” “The Betamax Controversy,” “Why Study Popular Culture?” “The Siyanga Pala Syndrome,” “Censorship,” and “For Teachers Only: Using Film to Teach Literature,” which was part of the Proceedings of the 1980 CETA Convention of 1981, 1981. Among the titles, the first presents Cruz’s framework for film appreciation, stipulating three elements that constitute his definition of a good movie: technical excellence, literary value, and cinematic sense. “Why Study Popular Culture?” acknowledges the importance of approaches drawn from sociology, history, and structuralism—a view capably realized by Cruz himself in a number of his critical works published after Movie Times.

In the end, the book can be said to indicate where Cruz has come from just as it also provides an effective recollection of a number of local film titles.  Written by Joel David

article_title: The National Pastime / Fields of Vision / Wages of Cinema
text:
THE NATIONAL PASTIME: CONTEMPORARY PHILIPPINE CINEMA

Published 1990 in Pasig City / Author: Joel David / Publisher: Anvil Publishing Inc

FIELDS OF VISION: CRITICAL APPLICATIONS IN RECENT PHILIPPINE CINEMA

Published 1995 in Quezon City / Author: Joel David / Publisher: Ateneo de Manila University Press

 

WAGES OF CINEMA: FILM IN PHILIPPINE PERSPECTIVE

Published 1998 in Quezon City / Author: Joel David / Publisher: University of the Philippines Press

 

Joel David released these three books on Philippine cinema in the last decade of the 20th century.

The National Pastime is a compilation of over 50 reviews of movies in the 1980s and critical essays on film that were published in National Midweek magazine, where David was “reviewer in residence.” He also discusses alternative works, such as short films, 16 mm, Super 8, video, television, komiks, stage, and book forms by reviewing notable or representative samples.

With an introduction by Bienvenido Lumbera, this book is divided into 10 sections. These are “Directors 1” (Eddie Romero and Mike de Leon), “Issue 1” (censorship, film reviewing, and criticism), “Genres” (horror, sex, and action), “Alternative 1” (formats), “Actors” (Niño Muhlach, Roderick Paulate, and Nora Aunor), “Directors 2” (Mario O’Hara and Peque Gallaga), “Issues 2” (the significance of the 1986 EDSA Revolt, the re-emergence of the studio system), “Genre” (melodrama), “Alternative 2” (media), and “Directors 3” (Ishmael Bernal and Lino Brocka).

The author opens the book with “A Second Golden Age (An Informal History),” an essay that takes its cue from Lumbera’s historicization of a new Philippine cinema. David proposes to mark the beginning of the period with Lino Brocka’s resurgence, particularly with his film Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), 1975, instead of basing it on the establishment of the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino (MPP) in 1976, and to end it with the EDSA Revolt in February 1986.

In the closing essay, “Ethics First (Rather Than Aesthetics),” David recommends formalist and structuralist approaches for local film practice. But in the epilogue, “Moving Picture: World’s Shortest Prequel,” he also offers ways to re-examine the wealth of ideas he presented in the book.

Whether he is evaluating masa comedies and melodramas, such as Kumander Gringa (Commander Gringa), 1988, and Nagbabagang Luha (Smoldering Tears), 1989, experimental forms like Bilanggo sa Dilim (Prisoner in the Dark), 1986, or a cause célèbre like Orapronobis (Fight for Us), 1989, David pulls out all the stops with his acerbic wit, masterful command of film theory and cinematic language, regard for history and culture, and passionate faith in cinema.

In Fields of Vision, David invests himself in a variety of critical enterprises and divides them into three parts: “Panorama,” “Viewpoints,” and “Perspectives.” “Panorama” is a lengthy and dense essay that pinpoints the “non- or anti-Hollywood influences in local cinema,” particularly how and where modifications or differences occurred. One such influence is neorealism, which is exemplified by the works of Italian directors such as Roberto Rossellini (Rome, Open City, 1945) and Vittorio De Sica (The Bicycle Thief, 1948). Neorealist films were marked by the primacy of sociopolitical themes, and the practice of using nonprofessional actors, actual locations, reasonable budgets, and basic equipment. Neorealism was perceived as a challenge and a conspicuous departure from the Hollywood model of film production.

David points out that when neorealism reached the country in the 1950s, its most prominent proponents were Lamberto Avellana, Anak Dalita (The Ruins), 1956, and Gregorio Fernandez, Malvarosa, 1958, who both worked within the local studio system. They were able to exhibit their neorealist tendencies in the so-called prestige products of studios—films meant for the international festival circuit. In short, even if they took their cues from the European neorealists, they succeeded in creating films that were “different” in the sense that these works could not have possibly matched the moneymaking ability of surefire hits. Instead, these prestige movies were aimed at earning international awards, citations, or plaudits to boost the studios’ image.

“Viewpoints” includes works David produced during his “comparative reviews” days. An example of this practice is “Woman-Worthy,” David’s take on Chito Roño’s Kasalanan Bang Sambahin Ka? (Is It a Sin to Worship You?), 1990, and Brocka’s Hahamakin Lahat (All Be Damned), 1990. David uses one critical heading for both films for good reason: they are melodramas with female leads who are unlike the long-suffering, passive Madonnas that Filipinos have gotten used to. Using this genre, Roño and Brocka get down and dirty—that is, they explore the desires and pleasures of the so-called bad girls instead. With this critical device, David frees himself to some degree from discussing the specifics of either film, thus leaving him with more room to expound on the generalities of both.

David’s “canonizing projects” are in “Perspectives.” An example is his “Ten Best” survey, which evolved from a group project of sorts during his stint as the secretary of the MPP. He eventually expanded his study and set definite criteria pertaining to data gathering and tabulation and the selection of respondents. His “Ten Best” lists focus on scholars, directors, critics, and screenwriters, among others.

In the third book, Wages of Cinema, David scrutinizes deconstruction, historiography, postcolonialism, and other trends in Western film discourse in a critical interrogation of Philippine cinema. The book is not so much about the films discussed or film-related trends and developments as much as it is about the conditions that make their existence possible. It is David’s attempt to situate or perhaps haul Philippine cinema onto the world stage, if you will.

The book has three main sections: “Subjectivities,” “Specificities,” and “Sexualities.” In a marked departure from the first two books, David also includes foreign films, such as Robert Altman’s Nashville, 1975, Nagisa Oshima’s In the Realm of the Senses, 1976, and Régis Wargnier’s Indochine, 1992, as texts for study. These were mostly used in reassessing questions regarding gender, genre and race, structure as well as autobiography, and authorship that the author posed in his earlier writings “in the light of how these may best contribute to the interest of Philippine film criticism, production, and viewership.”  Written by Eileen Ang

article_title: National/Transnational: Subject Formation and Media in and on the Philippines
text:
Published 2001 in Quezon City / Author: Rolando B. Tolentino / Publisher: Ateneo de Manila University Press

This book analyzes the media representations of the Philippine nation as well as the cultural politics involved in the formation of the Filipino subject through transnational media. The national, according to Tolentino, refers to the “disjunctures, primarily those generated from within, in which the nation… comes into being and ceaselessly defines itself.” While the transnational refers to “the contending ways that capital, systems of power and knowledge, cosmopolitanism, urbanity, modernity, and postmodernity are penetrated within the nation’s own being.” For Tolentino, the critique of power “can materialize only by interfacing the national and the transnational.”

Given this framework, Tolentino offers an evaluation of several texts in the three sections that constitute the book. The first section, “National/Transnational Disjuncture,” juxtaposes the contending issues in the formation of the nation and the various representations of the Filipina. The first chapter of the section reads into the advertisements of mail-order brides. article_title: Native Resistance: Philippine Cinema and Colonialism, 1898 to 1941
text:
Published 1998 in Manila / Author: Clodualdo del Mundo Jr / Publisher: De La Salle University Press

In this book, Clodualdo A. del Mundo contends that culture was a tool used by both the Spanish and American colonizers to further their conquest of the Philippines. However, he argues that the colonizers’ tool was also a site of decolonization and “native resistance.”

Through a careful analysis of four extant prewar Filipino films—Giliw Ko (My Love) and Tunay na Ina (Real Mother), 1939; Pakiusap (Plea), 1940; and Ibong Adarna (Adarna Bird), 1941—this book traces how traditional Spanish theatrical forms were indigenized into distinctly Filipino genres, such as the moro-moro and the sarsuwela. It also explores how the technology and practice of film arrived at a time of turbulent transition: the 300-year Spanish regime was drawing to a bloody close, the fires of revolution fueled the birth of the Filipino nation, and the Americans began their ruthless occupation of the Philippines with a lethal mix of culture and violence.

Within this historical context, del Mundo tracks how native resistance continued with the adaptation of cinema itself, borrowing heavily from the traditions of moro-moro and sarsuwela. As such, the book debunks the common view of these movies as paltry imitations of glamorous Hollywood productions. Instead, it shows how Filipino films from this era were products of a foreign medium that was localized and modified to suit the sensibilities and realities of the native milieu.

The author, however, concedes that these films take on the colonizer’s worldview, affirming the superiority of the imperialist, who rightly lords over his inferior—the native. In insidious but marked ways, this perspective made its presence known and felt. Heroic characters were portrayed by movie stars with refined, Caucasian features while villainous and second-fiddle roles were played by dark-skinned, dim-witted simpletons. Film plots seemed to champion the virtuous but downtrodden poor, but in reality they glorified the privileged and benevolent elite.

The book concludes with a chapter titled “Looking as Bondage,” which discusses how local filmmakers still struggle to break free of this colonial legacy. It is up to them to retrace their roots and examine complex issues such as representation with fresh eyes, argues del Mundo. Because without new ways of seeing, Philippine cinema is doomed to remain shackled to the same old blinders that obscure meaning and meaningful work.  Written by Eileen Ang

Published 1989 in Manila / Author: Emmanuel A. Reyes / Publisher: De La Salle University Press

This is a collection of critical essays as well as a transcription of Reyes’s 1984 documentary Vic Silayan: An Actor Remembers. The book contains 14 film reviews previously published between 1984 and 1987. They deal with Snake Sisters, Kapitan Inggo: Kumakain ng Bala (Captain Inggo: Bullet-Eater), and ’Merika (America), 1984; Isla (Island), Boatman, Virgin Forest, Bomba Queen (Porn Queen), Miguelito: Batang Rebelde (Miguelito: Young Rebel), Scorpio Nights, and Silip (Daughters of Eve), 1985; Bagong Hari (New King), 1986; and Olongapo … The Great American Dream, 1987.

The essays include “Form in the Filipino Film,” “Myth and Philippine Cinema,” “Murder by Frame,” “Black and White in Color: The Lure of Komiks Movies,” “Does Political Repression Make Good Cinema?,” “Images of Ourselves in Our Own Reality,” “Why Does Somebody Else Have to Tell the Story of Our Revolution?,” and “The Aesthetics of the Short Film.” These constitute the author’s articulation of his approaches to the appreciation of cinema in general and that of the Philippines in particular. The first two average about 30 pages each.

“Form in the Filipino Film” draws significantly from David Bordwell’s “Classical Hollywood Cinema,” Bordwell and Kristin Thompson’s Film Art: An Introduction, and W. Tatarkiewicz’s “Form in the History of Aesthetics” in the Dictionary of the History of Ideas by Philip Weiner. After discussing Sister Stella L., 1984, in the context of “classical Hollywood cinema,” Reyes opines that mainstream Filipino film has evolved its own narrative form, different from that of the Hollywood film. Hence, its conventions should not be seen as “flaws” but rather as “traits.” Reyes then enumerates four formal traits manifested in Philippine cinema: “a scene-oriented narrative, a tendency for overt representation, circumlocutory dialog, and a narrative that emphasizes the centrality of the star.”

“Myth and Philippine Cinema” has a five-part outline, consisting of the subtitles “Stranger Than Fiction,” “On Themes, Messages, Symbols and Realism,” “The World on Her Shoulders: Women in Melodrama,” “Macho Fantasies: Philippine Cinema’s Action Heroes,” and “Gay and Really Useful: Homosexuality and Philippine Cinema.” Here Reyes once more appropriates the same assertion in “Form in the Filipino Film” and suggests “myth in relation to a society’s value system as revealed by cinema” as an additional subject for study.  Written by Joel David

Published 1982 in Manila / Editor: Rafael Ma. Guerrero / Publisher: Experimental Cinema of the Philippines (ECP)

This is an anthology of 26 articles grouped into four general topics. The articles in the section “History” include Santiago A. Pilar’s “The Early Movies,” P. T. Martin’s “The ‘Silent Pictures’ Era in the Philippines,” Celso Al. Carunungan’s “Early Years of Philippine Movies,” Jessie B. Garcia’s “The Golden Decade of Filipino Movies,” Agustin Sotto’s “The Celluloid Route of Genghis Khan,” and Bienvenido Lumbera’s “Problems in Philippine Film History.” The section “Themes and Interpretations” includes Nicanor G. Tiongson’s “From Stage to Screen: Philippine Dramatic Traditions and the Filipino Film,” Petronilo Bn. Daroy’s “Social Significance and the Filipino Cinema,” Guerrero’s “Tagalog Movies: A New Understanding,” and Jose F. Lacaba’s “Notes on ‘Bakya’: Being an Apologia of Sorts for Filipino Masscult.” Essays in the section “Stars and Their Public” include Andres Cristobal Cruz’s “Remembrance of Movies Past” and features by Virgilio S. Almario on Nora Aunor, by Quijano de Manila aka Nick Joaquin on Fernando Poe Jr, by Denise Chou Allas on Dolphy, and by Jullie Yap-Daza on Eddie Rodriguez. The last section, “Directors and the Industry,” contains Amadis Ma. Guerrero’s “Gerardo de Leon: A Master Filmmaker Speaks Out”; Charles Tesson’s “Gerardo de Leon: An Amazing Discovery” and “The Cult of the Image in Lino Brocka”; T. D. Agcaoili’s “Lamberto V. Avellana: A National Artist and His Times”; Eddie Romero’s “My Work and Myself,” “A Film Director Speaks Out,” and “Film Censorship and Social Change”; Rafael Ma. Guerrero’s “Lino Brocka: Dramatic Sense, Documentary Aspirations”; Mario A. Hernando’s “Ishmael Bernal: Merging Art and Commercialism”; and Lino Brocka’s “Philippine Movies: Some Problems and Prospects.”

As manifested in the scope of its concerns, the book aims to encourage an appreciation of its subject matter in both beginner and connoisseur, native or foreign. Guerrero’s introduction, cognizant of the then sincere aspirations of his publisher, the Marcos-era ECP, announces: “Signs abound towards that unravelling progress of the Philippine cinema. For the first time it has become possible to believe that Tagalog movies cannot but become better …” Thus, one can detect the wide-ranging optimism manifested in the arrangement of articles. Observations of various problematics are limited to the historical first half of the book. In the second half are unquestionably favorable assessments of accomplishments in Philippine cinema.  Written by Joel David

article_title: Richard Gomez at ang Mito ng Pagkalalake, Sharon Cuneta at ang Perpetwal na Birhen at Iba Pang Sanaysay ukol sa Bida sa Pelikula bilang Kultural na Texto
text:
(Richard Gomez and the Myth of Maleness, Sharon Cuneta and the Perpetual Virgin and Other Essays on Lead Actors in the Movies as Cultural Texts) / Published 2000 in Pasig City / Author: Rolando B. Tolentino / Publisher: Anvil Publishing Inc

This book explores how films have become an extension of reality and how reality has been extended by films. Filipino stars who usually attain fame by playing quintessential heroes and heroines in films are palimpsests of collective desires. Moreover, these desires are not just limited to the realm of fantasy; they also take form and are played out in life.

Tolentino asserts that, in the Philippines, stardom is a vehicle for success. As such, stars are the embodiments of possibility offered by material prosperity. Their ubiquity—in movies, television, print materials, etc.—legitimizes the forms of aspiration they represent.

The showbiz industry, then, does not produce mere stars. The forces of meaning-making are always at work: these stars are bodies that enable certain modes of seeing and being, personifying values and ideals acceptable to society. In short, these stars are cultural texts/products that audiences “buy into” by subscribing to the value system that each star glorifies. As such, the production of meaning is a collective endeavor, one that necessitates some measure of complicity among its collaborators, willing or not.

Some of the stars/cultural texts that Tolentino systematically reads are Sharon Cuneta, Aga Muhlach, and Judy Ann Santos. He maps out the interplay of their film-specific and film-related roles, verifiable facts of their private lives with the value systems they embody, thus demonstrating how the “text” that is readily identifiable as “Sharon” or “Aga” or “Judy Ann” is formed, and why it is interpreted as such.

Through this book, a vital but under-scrutinized part of Philippine showbiz is given serious albeit indirect consideration: fandom. On the surface, the ardent and borderline-obsessive adoration of Noranians and Vilmanians for their idols—Nora Aunor and Vilma Santos, respectively—seems like an embarrassingly popular affliction among the Filipino masa or public, who naively need to believe in make-believe. But when viewed through the lens of cultural criticism, Filipino showbiz fans are revealed to be more than just eager cogs of a profit-driven, myth-building machine. They are also active participants in a pervasive social phenomenon that shows no signs of abating, not while the desire to escape or recast, even temporarily, the mundane and sometimes oppressive realities of their ordinary lives persists.  Written by Eileen Ang

THE URIAN ANTHOLOGY

1970-1979

Published 1983 in Manila / Edited, Compiled, and With an Introduction by Nicanor G. Tiongson / Publisher: Manuel L. Morato

 

THE URIAN ANTHOLOGY

1980-1989

Published 2001 in Manila / Edited, Compiled, and With an Introduction by Nicanor G. Tiongson / Publisher: Antonio P. Tuviera

 

THE URIAN ANTHOLOGY

1990-1999

Published 2010 in Quezon City / Edited, Compiled, and With an Introduction by Nicanor G. Tiongson / Publishers: University of the Philippines Press and Film Development Council of the Philippines

 

THE URIAN ANTHOLOGY 2000-2009: THE RISE OF THE PHILIPPINE NEW WAVE INDIE FILM

Published 2013 in Quezon City / Edited, Compiled, and With an Introduction By Nicanor G. Tiongson / Publishers: University of the Philippines Press and Film Development Council of the Philippines.

 

The first anthology sets the template that will be followed by the later volumes. It features the following sections: (1) in-depth studies of Philippine cinema, its history, and various aspects; (2) evaluations of popular genre films; (3) critiques of films with “artistic vision and integrity,” which constitute what the Manunuri ng Pelikulang Pilipino (MPP) considers “New Cinema”; (4) features and portraits of film artists and personalities; (5) the criteria, list of winners, and citations of the annual Gawad Urian; and (6) an exhaustive filmography of the whole decade.

The second volume, The Urian Anthology, 1980-1989, continues where the previous anthology left off. It offers a frame of reference for appreciating Filipino films produced in the equally unstable years of the 1980s, when Benigno Aquino Jr was assassinated and the wave of anti-Marcos protests intensified, when the 1986 EDSA Revolt forced Marcos and his family into exile, and when pockets of the military (unsuccessfullly) staged several coups d’état to unseat President Corazon C. Aquino. The volume also covers the establishment of the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines and the Film Academy of the Philippines.

The third volume, The Urian Anthology, 1990-1999, gives an account of what may be considered “the worst of times, the best of times” of Philippine cinema when the film industry celebrated the 75th year of the Filipino film, the 100th year of the first Lumiere films, and the centennial celebrations of the revolution against Spain, the declaration of Philippine independence, and the proclamation of the first Philippine Republic, even as it sunk deeper into unmitigated commercialism and escapism.

The fourth volume, The Urian Anthology 2000-2009, chronicles the rise of “the new wave indie films” whose coming was hoped for and heralded just before the end of the 20th century and alluded to in the third volume. The volume covers the conditions that gave rise to the indie film, the different producers and artistic styles of the indie film, and the best examples of the indie film from 2005 to the end of the decade.

The Urian anthologies are historically significant in a number of ways. The introductions written by Tiongson, the series editor, altogether provide a history of Philippine cinema, as well as analyses of this cinema’s political economy, problems, and artistic highlights, from 1970 to 2009. These are supplemented by essays of Bienvenido Lumbera and Agustin L. Sotto that chronicle film history prior to the 1970s. The winners of the Gawad Urian eventually exert some form of presence in tentative film canons, and the artists memorialized in the volumes find a place in the ongoing historiography of Philippine film. The photographic illustrations, documents, and filmographies offer a wealth of resources for researchers, scholars, and film enthusiasts.

The film essays and reviews demonstrate the various critical frameworks and methodologies employed by the MPP in their readings of film texts. These writings were contributed by members and former members of the MPP—namely, Tiongson, Lumbera, Sotto, as well as Grace Javier Alfonso, Mario E. Bautista, Behn Cervantes, Isagani R. Cruz, Petronilo Bn. Daroy, Joel David, Paul Daza, Pio de Castro III, Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, Justino M. Dormiendo, Mauro Feria Tumbocon Jr, Butch Francisco, Tito Genova Valiente, Christian Ma. Guerrero, Alice G. Guillermo, Mario A. Hernando, Jose Sevilla Ho, Ricardo Lee, Cristina Pantoja-Hidalgo, Ellen Paglinauan, Tezza O. Parel, Manuel S. Pichel, Miguel Q. Rapatan, Emmanuel A. Reyes, Jun Cruz Reyes, Benilda S. Santos, Rolando B. Tolentino, Nestor U. Torre, and Joselito Zulueta.  Written by Patrick Campos

The volume covers the conditions that gave rise to the indie film, the different producers and artistic styles of the indie film, and the best examples of the indie film from 2005 to the end of the decade.

The Urian anthologies are historically significant in a number of ways. The introductions written by Tiongson, the series editor, altogether provide a history of Philippine cinema, as well as analyses of this cinema’s political economy, problems, and artistic highlights, from 1970 to 2009. These are supplemented by essays of Bienvenido Lumbera and Agustin L. Sotto that chronicle film history prior to the 1970s. The winners of the Gawad Urian eventually exert some form of presence in tentative film canons, and the artists memorialized in the volumes find a place in the ongoing historiography of Philippine film. The photographic illustrations, documents, and filmographies offer a wealth of resources for researchers, scholars, and film enthusiasts.

The film essays and reviews demonstrate the various critical frameworks and methodologies employed by the MPP in their readings of film texts.
